comments.commentBody: While I think banning smokers is going a bit far, I am all for a ban on smoking during (or just before) work hours.  The smell of smoke emanating from hair, skin and clothes is much stronger than some people realize.  I recently had to complain because a hospital tech came into my 2 year old daughter's hospital room reeking of smoke.  Sure, he wasn't smoking on campus, but working in a position where he is required to stand within close proximity of others (especially others with potential health issues) should require that he be completely smoke-free.

Finally, a good decision but this will also open up a Pandora's box. The approach used here that smokers won't be hired secondary to their habit, is also fraught with bias.
If this measure is fully adopted, well.... then ALCOHOL has been shown to have a worse profile compared to heroine and cocaine when it comes to addiction. How many good workers are lost secondary to alcohol related habits, how many families destroyed by it: too many to count.

Smoking, alcohol and drugs-- variable degrees of addiction, different modes of effecting mental health and human productivity but in the end it all boils down to the same-- addictive substances with capacity to ruin human mind and body.

As an example, tobacco related diseases and associated health studies laid down the role of cigarette smoking in gory details in 80s and 90s and so many years later, cigarette smoking is still here. In the same vein, two major studies on alcohol's damaging effects (so undermined all the time), one from U of Toronto and the other from UK, finally got through the severe backlash from Wine/Liquor industry.

And I am just waiting for the day when tobacco and alcohol like these drugs (heroine, cocaine, LSD, hash, methamphetamine, etc) will be labeled illegal and controlled substances.

Is this is a good way to deter smokers---- sneaky and a tad mean as well but effective all the same.
Also after it has been proved how third-party smoking can cause asthma and related respiratory symptoms in children esp., more the reason to find ways to eradicate tobacco.
Now, if humans would finally realize what alcohol has done to us for millennia, then we're getting somewhere.

Folks howling for ethics/human rights violation may say, "If I want to kill myself, who are you to stop me".... well, my answer would be, then pray go and do it on a deserted island, from where you family and friends can't drag your half rotten corpse to hospitals to get treatment.

I dislike having to smell smoke when I am serviced by someone who emanates that smell. It is a reason for me to discontinue at a doctor's office or any other establishment. I can't smell someone's belief, gender, nationality, sexual orientation....but I can smell smoke and be affected detrimentally from it. I don't think this is a freedom/rights issue. A healthcare setting should offer as healthy as possible an experience to its clientele.

Perhaps the need to be employed gainfully will be stronger than the desire to smoke and contaminate other people and the work environment.  Granted that this move threatens our shared habits of being too fat, and not watching what and how much we consume, and generally ignoring our bad, though legal habits.  Many preach solutions which are generally ignored.  When it impacts a pocketbook issue, there begins to be real consequences, hence, motivation to make important life choices, and thereby avoid smoking related illnesses which cost everyone a lot, and especially the smoker.  I have watched family die of smoking related illnesses, and it is truly misery.

Mubarak has been so good at amassing a fortune by ripping off the Egyptians he should be offered an honorary position on Wall Street.  Think of the money he could make on the lecture circuit.  This offer should lure him into stepping down.
We needed a distraction to keep our masses from knowing that our Supreme Court decided that Obamacare was unconstitutional.
He is old, stubborn and delusional. He won't leave. The only way to sideline him is to shoot him dead, preferably with his vice. Army may find it necessary to do just that.

My 8 year old son and I were talking about Egypt on the way home from school today. We've both been following the events, (he had a snow day when Mubarak had his first address to the protesters, we thought he'd step down then) and I told him about the expectation of the speech today and the actual outcome. I mentioned there was speculation that the army had been preparing for a coup. He got to talking about it all and said that it would be really interesting if the army did a haiku.

It is foolish to believe that we have limited power to shape developments in Egypt.  If nothing else we provide a backstop and a foundation on which Mubarak and his cohort can craft a rational response and excuse for remaining in power.  To have the head of the CIA speculate publicly about a supposed outcome is to invite the opposite which has indeed happened.  Far too much has already been said by US officials beyond offering support for the goals of the Egyptian public.  It is one thing for the press to speculate about the events in Egypt and quite another for Officials of the United States Government to speculate about those same events.

Let the bravery of the Egyptian people be an inspiration to all people who live under governments that don't listen to them. In this country we must remember that we already have the rights of free speech, press, the right to gather. We who live in democracies must always remind ourselves that our politicians serve us, not the other way around. They are elected to serve ALL the people, not just the rich.I think leaders all over the world are nervous about these Egyptian revolts. Worldwide, the huge gap between life for the rich and everyone else grows wider every year. What if regular people everywhere started demanding that their governments started taking care of ALL it's people?

Just have to get this out of my system: all of these Arab regimes, like this one here, and obviously there is many more throughout the world: what a disgrace.
What an absolute disgrace for humanity having to see or much less live in it, in the year 2011.
Repression, shameless lying, wanton torture, while those in power enrich themselves ruthlessly.....
My heart goes out to all of those heroes who have come to the point of no return and have to now continue to get together and protest and possibly give their own lives.

What is it he does not understand? His "people" want him and his buddies out. The billions of $ we sent Egypt likely ended up padding his pockets. How humiliating that we were fooled by a dictator. He shows his true colors by denying the people their wishes. He is a dictator, a ruler, a narcissistic old man who can't let go of power. He is no better than Saddam Hussein and we killed him. Remember?

Mubarak is over 80 years old.
Statistically - there is an 30% chance that he suffering from some form of dementia.
His speech today could be one indicator.

I fear for the prostesters because Mubarak will use any means at hand to quell the revolt.  That includes the most brutal forms.  And I feel certain the White House has been informed by the Egyptian government of exactly what they plan to do...and have at least been given tacit approval.

Can America afford to be on the sideline?  For the past 30 years we have propped up the Egyptian dictator in the name of stability. N ow that things aren't so stable what is the administration doing?  Americans is already seen by many Egyptians as backing the regime and not the peoples cause. When this regime falls, and it will due to populace anger, which side should America be known to have sided with?  So let's be with the victor and not have such short sighted mind set. Let's undo the past 30 years.  Let's look at the next 30 years of peace and be known by those people America's true values.

I never thought I would say this----and it pains me to do so:

I no longer love this country.

The America I once loved....no longer exists. The country where you could turn on a television program and not be assaulted by commercials for penile enlargement or women's masturbatory products. The country where the television programs themselves were not a teeming cesspool of vulgarity, obscenity and rot.

A country not under siege by the extremes of demagogic thinking, but by a sensible, centrist middle ground. A wise and fair middle ground, where one could possess a catalog of human frailties, yet still be respected----and tolerated. A country of human beings.

Human beings who sometimes over-indulged, but were never commanded to be less indulgent. Who sometimes over-ate, or ate the wrong things. Or smoked, or drank, or maybe experimented with a sundry of other temptations, but were never punished for it. Or looked down upon for their choices, or had those choices legislated by fiat right out of existence.

No, the America I once loved is a rapidly dying place, as I am a dying breed. And this is good, as I don't think I could live much longer in this place.

I don't think anyone will ever again truly "live" in this place called the United States of America.

Those who use obesity and preexisting conditons as analogous to smoking are using flawed logic.  Cigarrettes are the only product that, when used exactly according to directions, even in moderation, still kills you.

I suspect that, ultimately, the military knows that Mubarak is disposible and not worth defending, should circumstances approach crisis proportions. He's 82 and has had a 30-year run. They'll check which way the wind blows, and won't want to be known as the "Mubarak supporters" after his downfall.

I believe that the Army will have to act quickly. They have one choice only. That is to side with the people. If they wait to long the people will take control without them. Then they would be weakened
For them to side with Mubarak at this point would either cause a revolt within the Army or they would be destroyed by a revolution.
I sincerely believe that the younger officers and the enlisted men are on the side of the protesters. They have to act quickly as they in fact can prevent a blood bath
I am a physician who treats respiratory disease and I have no love of smoking or cigarette companies. However, to me, this reeks of discrimination.

Education level is one of the biggest predictors of who is a smoker. It is a bad idea to decrease job availability for a population that has a hard enough time finding work. Sure, there is no place for smoking at a hospital - but this is certainly not the answer

25% of the population are smokers.

60% are obese.

Who is taxing our healthcare system more?

Enough with persecuting smokers.
Why not ban people who drink, eat fatty foods, don't exercise, etc.

If they're going to ban smokers, why don't they ban fat people.  After all their visibility in the public eye is a tacit endorsement of their lifestyle.  Think it won't happen?  You haven't been watching the fine print coming out of the health care business.
that is interfering in one's personal life. It is not acceptable at all
